English: Night time, front lines
Evening, central Kolguyev
Any news from Stas?
Not yet. Have patience, Sergei. We must be slow and methodical.
I understand. I am just wary.
We all are. But tell me, Sergei, your father's letters, what he did write you about?
Well, mostly he was worried about me actually. Crazy given that he was in a middle of a war and I was still to secondary school.\nBut sometimes he would tell me about the war and his feelings.
He said he had doubts. He did not believe the war was justified and right. He did not like how the war was going.\nHe must have been talking about the nuclear warhead, right?
Surely, but there might be more in his words.
Like what?
Your father was a very progressive man. He believed in justice but not the one that we possess.\nHe believed in equality and freedom for everyone.
Are you implying my father was a dissident?

I'm just telling you facts. He would never go against the Soviet Union, you can be sure of that.\nHe loved his country in the same way we all do.\nBut he did believe there were things which could have been done differently. Better.
I think I understand. We never spoke of it, but what you say makes sense.\nI must say I share this ideal. I am no traitor but I am not blind as to not see our shortcomings.
Then we are in the same boat. I am glad for that. You truly are your father's son.

Thanks, Grigory. My father would be proud no doubt. What I would give to have him by my side.\nI never told you but I have never forgiven the Americans for shooting him. I understand it was a war but I will never forgive them.\nIf I knew the person who pulled the trigger I would shoot him in a heartbeat like he shot my father.

You said you knew him, Grigory. How come he died that day? What is the chaos of retreat? Did he cover our units while they escaped?\nTo this day I still have no official word of what happened. But you were there! Weren't you?

It was chaos, Sergei, more than you can even imagine. A lot happened in the last days of that blasted war.\nBut we should not dwell on the past. I have a mission in few hours and have to get ready.\nI'll see you later, Sergei, good luck out there.
IVAN TO DMITRI, WE'RE READY WHEN YOU ARE. WAITING FOR YOUR SIGNAL. OUT.
DMITRI TO IVAN. GO IN, WEAPONS FREE. OVER.
UNDERSTOOD DMITRI. OUT.
THE CROSSROADS ARE TAKEN. GIVE US A MOMENT TO REGROUP BEFORE MOVING ON.
WE'RE READY TO ADVANCE ON THE CAMP, DMITRI. WAITING FOR YOUR SIGNAL. OUT.
DMITRI TO IVAN, HIT THE CAMP. WE'RE RIGHT BEHIND YOU. OVER.
BAZA TO DMITRI, GOOD WORK, THE VALLEY IS OURS. ADVANCE TO THE MOUNTAINTOP. WATCH YOUR STEP AND REPORT WHEN YOU'VE DEALT WITH THE AA. BAZA OUT.
DMITRI TO BAZA, THE AA IS ABLAZE. CHOPPERS HAVE FREE REIGN OVER THE SKIES, OVER.
GOOD WORK, DMITRI. AIRBORNE UNITS ARE ON THEIR WAY. HOLD THE MOUNTAINTOP TILL THEY ARRIVE. BAZA OUT.
BMP'S DOWN. TREAD CAREFULLY NOW!
IVAN'S OUT. WE'LL HAVE TO MANAGE ON OUR OWN.
Mountaintop
Crossroads
Camp
Ivan
CROSSROADS
CAMP
MOUNTAINTOP
Ivan to attack crossroads
Ivan to attack camp
0-0 - Radio menu\n1 - send code Anton
0-0 - Radio menu\n2 - send code Boris
